thread.title: Woman 'who bullied man to death by throwing burgers at him' charged with manslaughter | Metro News
thread.title_full: Woman 'who bullied man to death by throwing burgers at him' charged with manslaughter | Metro News

author: Richard Hartley-Parkinson For Metro.Co.Uk
title: Woman 'who bullied man to death by throwing burgers at him' charged with manslaughter | Metro News
text:
Richard Hartley-Parkinson for Metro.co.uk Thursday 16 Feb 2017 12:15 pm Harley Branham has been charged with involuntary manslaughter (Picture: Good Morning America) 
A woman has been charged with involuntary manslaughter after she allegedly bullied a teenage worker to death. 
It is reported that Harley Branham, 21, left Kenneth Suttner, 17, feeling suicidal by ridiculing him and forcing him to complete humiliating tasks. 
One one occasion she is alleged to have thrown a cheese burger at him when he made it wrong, while on another she is said to have made him clean the floor by hand while lying on his stomach. 
Kenneth took his own life outside his home in December in Glasgow, Missouri. He was humiliated at Dairy Queen where they worked together Picture: Google Street View) Kenneth Suttner ended up taking his own life (Picture: Family handout) 
Now his former manager has appeared in court on involuntary manslaughter charges after a jury ruled that he had been bullied to death and Branham ‘was the principal cause of death’. 
Following that ruling, Kenneth’s family said: ‘it is long overdue that the issue of bullying be brought to light’. 
She did not enter a plea when she appeared in court and was released on bail. If found guilty she could face four years in prison. 
The court heard that they both worked together at Dairy Queen in Fayette, Missouri. To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video 
At an earlier hearing she said: ‘There’s a lot of people at Dairy Queen saying I was the reason he killed himself but I don’t understand why it would be that way.’ 
Dairy Queen was also found negligent in its training and the Glasgow School District failed to stop the bullying. US to find out if it can survive 'A Day Without Immigrants' 
Her lawyer said: ‘We look forward to the opportunity to present additional evidence and reviewing the evidence that the state intends to present in court.’ 
The school district says they were not allowed to comment properly at the hearing while Dairy Queen said the store was run by a franchisee. ‘Our thoughts and prayers continue to be with the Suttner family. We are still in the process of gathering information but understand from the franchisee that the manager is no longer employed at this location.’ Need support? Contact the Samaritans 
For emotional support you can call the Samaritans 24-hour helpline on 116 123 , email , visit a Samaritans branch in person or go to the Samaritans website . More
